net.sf.mmm.util.datatype.api.color

Class Color

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.sf.mmm.util.lang.api.AbstractDatatype
      • net.sf.mmm.util.lang.api.AbstractSimpleDatatypeBase<V>
        • net.sf.mmm.util.lang.api.AbstractSimpleDatatype<Integer>
          • net.sf.mmm.util.datatype.api.color.Color
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, AttributeReadValue<Integer>, Datatype, SimpleDatatype<Integer>

    public class Color
extends AbstractSimpleDatatype<Integer>
    This is the Datatype for a Color. It is based on values for red, green, getBlue(), and alpha. Internally these values are encoded in a single ARGB value. This class is similar to AWT Color but GWT compatible (AWT color is linked with AWT, see e.g. createContext) and especially compatible to CSS.
    For transformations and other ColorModels use GenericColor.
    ATTENTION:
    Unfortunately the alpha value has NOT been designed as a transparency value (inverse logic so 0 means no transparency or in other words a regular color). Then if encoding in A/R/G/B the hexadecimal RGB notation would be compatible with transparency because #2F4F8F would be the same as #002F4F8F. Unfortunately pain is on our side and we have to keep with existing standards. Therefore #2F4F8F is actually the same as #FF2F4F8F. To avoid confusion and to be compatible with CSS, toString() will print the hexadecimal RGB form (e.g. #2F4F8F) in case alpha has its maximum value (255/FF). Otherwise the CSS RGBA notation is used (e.g. rgba(47,79,143,0.5) instead of #7F2F4F8F).
    Since:
    1.0.0
    Author:
    Joerg Hohwiller (hohwille at users.sourceforge.net)
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • fromName

        public static Color fromName(String name)
        Parameters:
        name - is the name of the Color (e.g. as defined in CSS). Case is ignored. Examples are "white", "maroon", "orange", "transparent", etc.
        Returns:
        the Color for the given name or null if no such Color is defined.

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Returns the official String representation of this Datatype. While the general contract of Object.toString() is very weak and mainly used for debugging, the contract here is very strong. The returned String has to be suitable for end-users and official output to any kind of sink.
        ATTENTION:
        This method is not supposed to do internationalization (I18N). See NlsMessage for this purpose and implement NlsObject if you want to support I18N/L10N.
        Specified by:
        toString in interface Datatype
        Overrides:
        toString in class AbstractSimpleDatatypeBase<Integer>
        Returns:
        the official String representation to display the value of this Datatype.
